  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
An appeals court panel today took a shot at the Bush
  administration’s terror-detention policies. The court ruled the
  administration cannot legally detain a U.S. resident suspected of ties
  to al Qaeda without charging him. Indefinite detention of civilians would
  have “disastrous consequences for the constitution and the
  country,” the court said. Wyatt Andrews will tell us about the man at
  the center of this case – Ali al-Marri – and what it could mean for
  the future of fighting terrorism within our country.
 
Meanwhile, fighting al Qaeda in Afghanistan is complicated by its neighbors
  – especially Pakistan,
  which is used as a safe haven by many terrorists. Our chief foreign
  correspondent Lara Logan will report on how the sanctuary provided by Pakistan’s tribal areas is taking a toll
  on Afghanistan.
 
In the United States, thousands of
  claims have been filed in recent years against the government alleging that
  required vaccinations caused autism in kids. The first test case among those
  began today in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims. The vast majority of
  research finds no link between vaccines and autism, but now it’s the
  court’s turn to chime in. Sharyl Attkisson will report.
 
In other health news, as a new study forecasts that
  the number of Alzheimer’s patients will quadruple by 2050, controversy
  is brewing over an experimental drug. Dr. Jon LaPook will have the story.
 
If you live in an urban area of the United States,
  you may have seen detailed pictures of your neighborhood, your street, your
  home and even yourself online
  – thanks to Google Maps. Is the Internet search-engine giant’s
  new “street view” a helpful navigation tool or an invasion of
  privacy? Daniel Sieberg will take a look.
 
Finally, if you watched the last episode of the
  Sopranos last night, chances are you either loved it or you hated it. Richard
  Schlesinger will report on the landmark last episode that has everybody talking.
 
I hope you’ll join us for these stories and
  more,
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
